lines.text: Ooh, we're going up!
That's right, we're going way up. Do you know where we're going?
No.
We're going right up to Heaven. You know, Shirley, Heaven is a very nice place. If we're good, we'll all live there someday.
Yes, I know.
My mother and father are there now.
So's my daddy. We're up pretty high now. Are we near Heaven?

[with practicing piano]
One and two and three and. One and two and three and. One and two and three and. One and two and...
Stop it! One and two and three and. One and two- is that all you know?

[runs to her mother]
Mama! Mama!
Mama! Mama! It's a good thing I am not your mama. That's enough to drive a man crazy. Things better be a little different around here or you're gonna see the last of me.
My daddy could fly better than anyone in the whole world, couldn't he?
That's right, better than anyone in the whole world. You know, your daddy and I were pals ever since we were about as big as you are. That's why I'm your godfather.
And then one day he cracked up and went away to Heaven, didn't he?
That's right.
I'll bet when I'm a pilot, I won't crack up.
When you're ready to be a pilot, we'll get you a big non-crackable ship. That reminds me, I found a scrapbook the other day with some pictures of your daddy and me in it. Would you like to see?
Oh, yes.
Who's that picture of?
Oh. A girl I used to know.
She's a pretty lady.
I used to think so. But it's not enough to be pretty on the outside. You've got to be pretty on the inside, too.
How can you be pretty in there?
By thinking the right thoughts and doing the right things. And eating plenty of spinach!
It's just a bit of a Christmas gift for Shirley.
You're so kind. I bought a few things for her, not very much of course. Things were different when her father was alive.
Yes, the poor young fellow. But it must be a comfort to know you're doing all you can for her. She's such a sweet child. Not like that Joy. There's a brat if ever one lived.
What are you gonna get for Christmas? I'm gonna get a pink dollhouse with real furniture and a real piano and a tennis racket and a great big doll.
I asked Santa Claus to bring me a doll.
There ain't any Santa Claus!
There is too!
There is not! My psychoanalyst told me there ain't any Santa Claus or fairies or giants or anything like that.
I'll bet you'd feel pretty bad tomorrow morning if you woke up and you didn't have any presents.
Well, I won't. Wanna know why? 'Cause I already peeked in the closet and saw 'em.
I don't care what you saw. There is a Santa Claus!
There ain't!
Mr. Smith, there is a Santa Claus, isn't there?
What did she say?
She said there isn't.
Then there is.
We showed her, didn't we?
We sure did. Thanks, Mr. Smith. I like you.
Then you're the only one around here that does. They don't like me, and I don't like them, either.
Higgins!
Yes, madam?
My cousin Miss Martin is arriving from New York tomorrow. I want to be sure that everything is done just right.
Yes, madam.
Thomas, you'll meet her plane in the morning.
Yes, madam.
I'm very anxious to show her that we can do things exactly as well out here as they do in the east.
Yes, madam.
I want perfect meals and perfect service.
Yes, madam.
And Mary, I hope you'll remember what I told you this morning about visitors.
Yes, madam.
I know who you are.
You do?
Sure, you're the lady who's coming to live at our house.
You're not little Joy, are you?
Oh, no, I'm Shirley.
Oh, I see.
Loop, isn't this the lady whose picture you have in your book?
Yeah. She's one of them.

Now I've got a present for you. This isn't from Santa Claus. This is from me to you. This is a magic ring, see? Just like in the fairy tales. If ever you're in trouble, or if you ever want me to do anything for you, you send me this ring, and I'll come.
Oh, it's so pretty. Thank you, Loop.
Hey, where's your little girl?
She's gone to a Christmas party.
I don't believe in Christmas.
You don't?
It's all a lot of nonsense.
Well, I don't feel that way about it.
Here.
[handing her some money]
Buy a Christmas present for Shirley from me. Christmas.
[scoffs]
Well! What do you make of that?
He never fooled me. He's only tough on the outside. Inside, he's soft as mush.
Now because today is Christmas, you can do anything that you want to do. What would you like to do best in the world?
You know what. Fly.
That's just what I thought. All right, Shirley, we're going for a ride. Just you and I.
Are we going way up high?
That's right, way up high.
Shirley, I've got something to tell you.
A story?
No, not a story. You know, ever since your daddy went to Heaven, your mother's been awful lonesome for him.
Yes, I know. Sometimes she cries and everything.
Today your mother got so lonesome for your daddy that she went to see him.
All the way up to Heaven?
All the way up to Heaven. They're up there together now.
You mean... my mother cracked up, too?
I'm sorry, dear.
As far as I can find out, there are no relatives.
Now what are we to do?
She's no concern of ours. We have neither a legal nor a moral responsibility.
But after all, the woman worked for us. People will naturally expect us to do something. Maybe one of those aviators would like to adopt her.
Well, if they do, let them go to court. All we can do is see that the little girl is placed in an institution.

Now listen to me, you two. I want you to understand just one thing. If you ever expect to get anything out of me, you're going to be human enough and decent enough to take Shirley into this house to live. I'll pay for her board and her clothes.
Why, Uncle Ned, that won't be necessary.
Well, naturally. We had no idea you felt this way about the child.
Well, I do. If you don't want her here, I guess I can find some other place for her. And I guess I can find another place for me, too!
What do you think?
I think you're an old softy.
Well, would you let them put a child like that in a home, would you?
In my home.
But you're not like those two in there. You're more like me. Where is Shirley?
She's down at the airport with Loop.
Loop? Who's Loop? Oh, I remember. He's that aviator fellow you were interested in.
Uh, yes.
Can't you forget the past?
Sure. I can forget a lot of things. I can forget that you and I were in love, and we were engaged to be married, and you walked out on me. All that is as dead as this.
[tosses away a burnt match]
But I can't forget that you made a fool of me. A man remembers something like that.
Would it make any difference if I said I'm sorry?
Not a bit. It's a little too late. But you didn't come all the way over here just to tell me that, did you?
No. I came to talk about Shirley. The Smythes want her to come and live with them.
Wait a minute. You mean that you and Uncle Ned sold the Smythes the idea, and they don't like it any too well, but in order to keep in good with Uncle Ned, they'll do it. Well, you can't have her.

Don't let your feelings for me interfere with the little girl's future. I know her father was your best friend. I know you love her very dearly. You must surely see that she can't live here in a barracks with a lot of men!
Shirley, would you like to go back to the Smythes' house and live there?
Do I have to?
For a little while, dear.
Are you gonna be there, too?
Yes, I am, dear, and we'll be together every day.
Well, if you'll be there, it'll be fine. I like you, and I like Mr. Smith.
All right, then, it's all settled.
Can't Loop come and live with us, too?
No, dear. Just at the moment, I'm afraid that can't be arranged.
Let's play hospital. I'll be the doctor, and you'll be the nurse. We'll get a big knife out of the kitchen and operate on your doll.
I don't want Mary Lou to be operated on.
I don't care. You have to play the way I want to.
I don't, either.
Yes, you do because this is my house and my yard and you're nothing but an old charity.
I am not!
Yes, you are because I heard my papa tell my mama so.
You're that aviator, aren't you? Well, I don't like airplanes.
Well, I don't like wheelchairs.
You stay in those airplanes long enough, and you'll end up in one! What's he doing here?
You see, Uncle Ned, he thinks it would be a good idea for Shirley to go and live with him.
What? He wants to take Shirley away? Are you married?
No, I'm not.
How much do you make?
Enough to support myself.
Where do you live?
At the airport.
Where do you eat?
In restaurants.
Well, you can't have her!
Oh yeah? Who says so?
I say so!
I've got more right to her than you have!
We'll see about that!

You told Shirley if she was ever in trouble to send you this ring. Well, I want to see if it's really a magic ring because I'm in trouble. You want Shirley, and I want Shirley. If you think hard for a minute, can't you figure a way out?
I don't get you at all.
Oh, dear. Do I have to propose?
Well, I did the last time.
Oh, Loop...
No. You don't have to propose. Maybe all this happened for a good reason. Maybe this time it'll last forever.
I don't approve of all these telephone calls, Mary.
I'm sorry.
And I don't approve of all these aviators who keep coming here to see your little girl.
She's sort of a pet with them. They all knew her father.

I know that, but I really can't have it. It isn't everyone who'd engage a maid with a small child. I have no fault to find with your work, but if you want to stay on with us, you'll have to correct these things.
You must practice your piano. You won't have to practice again until after Santa Claus comes.
There ain't any Santa Claus!
Don't say ain't, darling, say isn't.
Ain't, ain't, ain't!
What's all this noise about?
Mama wants me to practice, and I don't wanna!
You must do as your mother says.
No, I ain't gonna!
Now, see here ...
Now, darling, remember what the psychoanalyst said. The child mind must never be coerced. One must use reason and persuasion. Now, dear, practice your piano and Mama will buy you something nice.
What?
Anything you like. What do you especially want?
A machine gun!
It's so wonderful of you boys to give Shirley her Christmas party.
We're getting a big kick out of it ourselves.
She'll be so surprised. She doesn't expect much, you know.
You get her down to the airport as early in the morning as you can.
I may not be able to come with her, but I'll be down just as soon as I can get away.
Mother, I dressed myself, and I put my clothes away, all folded and everything.
Well, you're your mother's little angel, that's what you are.
No, I'm not, because angels have wings, like these.
Those are your daddy's pilot wings.
I know, and now he's really an angel, isn't he?
Yes, darling.
You can take her now, but only on the understanding that once I get a place for her, Shirley comes with me. I love that baby.
I understand how you feel. Loop, regardless of what you think of me, I think you're the finest man I've ever known.
And another thing. You stop telling people I made my money in sanitary engineering. It was sewers. Sewers! And don't you forget it.

[about Uncle Ned]
Every time he sees me, he makes a face at me.
Why, Uncle Ned, why didn't you call us?
Call you? I yelled, and I shouted and I bellowed. A thanks lot of good it did me. No one pays any attention to me. No one cares what happens to me. All you do is think of yourselves.
Oh, Uncle Ned, you know that isn't so.
Mary!
Yes, Mr. Symthe.
My name is Smith. His name is Symthe.
Yes, Mr. Smith.
Didn't you hear me holler a little while ago?
No, sir, I didn't.
These folks around here better get their ears fixed.

[finds one of Joys of dolls by the incinerator]
Why, you poor little thing. You must have cracked up. You should be in the hospital.
Hey, that's my doll.
Well, I just found her here.
You can't have her.
[rips the doll out of Shirley's arms]
You bad old thing. You ran away from home and I'm gonna spank you
[spanks the doll]
If you give her to me, I'll take care of her. I'll wash her face and make her some clothes and everything.
You can't have her. You wanna know why? Because I'm gonna kill her.
[rips off the dolls limps and head before skipping away]

[Last line]
Oh, Papa... now we don't have to be nice to Uncle Ned anymore!
[her mother slaps her and she starts bawling]
